meanings.def: a long English poem written in the 14th century by an unknown author. It is about Sir Gawain, a knight at the court of King Arthur, who is told to perform various tasks by the mysterious Green Knight as a test of his faith. The poem is admired for its fine language and is regarded as one of the greatest poems of the period. Some people think it was written to celebrate the Order of the Garter.

the most famous of King Arthur's Knights of the Round Table, sometimes called Lancelot of the Lake. He was Arthur's favourite knight, but deceived him by becoming the lover of Queen Guinevere, Arthur's wife. Sir Galahad was his son by Elaine, the daughter of King Pelles.

the name of an old English country dance. In early issues of The Spectator magazine, Richard Steele and Joseph Addison wrote under the name 'Roger de Coverley', presenting him as a typical English country gentleman.
used as a polite way of addressing a man whose name you do not know, for example in a shop or restaurant
examples: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
Are you ready to order, sir?
‘Thank you very much.’ ‘You're welcome, sir. Have a nice day.’

meanings.def: used at the beginning of a formal business letter when you do not know the name of the man or people that you are dealing with
a title that is used before the first name of a man who has received one of the highest British honours (= a knight), or before the first name of a baronet
used as a form of address to a man in a position of authority, especially in the armed forces
used as a form of address by children in school to a male teacher
examples: Please, sir, can I open a window?
We will never allow that to happen! No sir!

meanings.def: used to emphasize that something is true
examples: That's a fine car you have. Yes sir!
We will never allow that to happen! No sir!

idioms.def: used to emphasize that something is true
examples: That's a fine car you have. Yes sir!
